title: In writing, how can I make sure that each one of my characters has their own unique voice? - Quora

response.answer_text: Ethan’s is a good answer. I don’t have the answer, but I will add a few things in the hope that it will attract someone who can actually answer this question. The first book I ever read that showed me how this is done is The Moonstone, by Wilkie Collins. The story itself is about a jewel theft, but what has made it famous is that each of the numerous characters has their own voice, way of speaking, accent or not, etc., and demonstrates this voice throughout. I don’t believe I’ve read a book since that displayed that kind of talent. In most of the books I read, the author doesn’t care, the same voice belongs to every character. They are lazy writers. I recommend that you read — no, study — The Moonstone which will help you to isolate voice in the speech of the people around you. If someone says to you, “That guy is a real character,” that’s somebody you want to listen to. Or “He’s got a lot of stories to tell,” ditto. Story tellers often have distinctive voices.

An important thing you have to know is that every one of your characters will have a little bit of you in them, because all of them are being written by you. That’s something that the biggest and best of authors will acknowledge. For me, personally, when I’m writing fiction, I find it difficult to come up with characters out of thin air. I believe that’s probably the case for most people, which is why I think that in many cases (certainly my own, I don’t actually want to speak for anyone else): the parts of a character that don’t come from you directly usually come from someone you know. Literally every character I’ve ever written has been at least partially inspired by a family member, friend, or person I met for five minutes at the supermarket and then never talked to again. If you are having trouble coming up with original characters or characters with their own unique voice, my advice is take inspiration from the people around you. Tweak different things about them and shape them into your characters. Since every real-life individual has their own voice, personality, etc., you should find your characters coming to life much easier. Check out my blog here: Film Reviews with Ethan J
